headline: {u'main': u'World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Deaths Linked To Tainted Water'}
snippet: Health officials say contamination of the water system in North Battleford, Saskatchewan, may have caused the death of 3 people and the illness of 100. Residents have been advised to boil water for a second week since parasites seeped into the dri...
lead_paragraph: Health officials say contamination of the water system in North Battleford, Saskatchewan, may have caused the death of 3 people and the illness of 100. Residents have been advised to boil water for a second week since parasites seeped into the drinking water. A year ago, 7 people died and 2,300 became ill in Walkerton, Ontario, after bacteria entered the town's water supply. A commission is investigating Canada's drinking water supplies and the qualifications of officials who run local water systems. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'U.S.-CANADA PACT ON NIAGARA IS SET'}
snippet: The United States and Canada agreed today to work for ''significant reductions'' in the contamination of the Niagara River by toxic chemicals.   A joint communique issued by Lee M. Thomas, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and ...
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada agreed today to work for ''significant reductions'' in the contamination of the Niagara River by toxic chemicals. A joint communique issued by Lee M. Thomas, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and Tom McMillan, Canada's Minister of the Environment, pledged the two nations to work toward a 50 percent reduction of some of the chemicals as a ''desirable'' target. In a separate agreement, meanwhile, Mr. McMillan and Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel signed a plan intended to build the continent's dwindling populations of wild ducks and geese.

headline: {u'main': u'SUPER-POWER PLAN BLOCKED IN CANADA; Project to Link Resources Across the Border With Ours Is Shelved.'}
snippet: The hope of a number of American and Canadian financiers to link together the great potential hydroelectric resources of the two neighboring nations has received a serious setback. It was learned yesterday that agitation in the Provinces of Quebec...
lead_paragraph: The hope of a number of American and Canadian financiers to link together the great potential hydroelectric resources of the two neighboring nations has received a serious setback. It was learned yesterday that agitation in the Provinces of Quebec and Ontario against the "export of Canadian power" has made impossible -- for the time being at least -- plans which have been in the making for several years.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Water Treatment Concern Acquired'}
snippet: General Electric said it agreed to acquire Zenon Environmental, a water treatment company in Canada, for about 760 million Canadian dollars ($646.4 million). General Electric said its water technologies unit would acquire Zenon, paying 24 Canadian...
lead_paragraph: General Electric said it agreed to acquire Zenon Environmental, a water treatment company in Canada, for about 760 million Canadian dollars ($646.4 million). General Electric said its water technologies unit would acquire Zenon, paying 24 Canadian dollars a share. Zenon makes supplies for water purification, wastewater treatment and water reuse for municipalities and industries. General Electric is based in Fairfield, Conn. Stock in Zenon, which is based in Oakville, Ontario, rose 8.28 Canadian dollars, or 53 percent, to 23.78 Canadian dollars a share.

headline: {u'main': u'The World; Pollution in Canada? Believe It.'}
snippet: FRAMED by three oceans, carved by the receding sheets of ice age glaciers, the world's second-largest country has great forests, crystal lakes and the bountiful granary of an endless prairie.   Canada: the very name calls up visions of snow-whitep...
lead_paragraph: FRAMED by three oceans, carved by the receding sheets of ice age glaciers, the world's second-largest country has great forests, crystal lakes and the bountiful granary of an endless prairie. Canada: the very name calls up visions of snow-whitepeaks jutting into a clean blue sky, of wolf and moose and mink roaming the woods and plains as they did for eons before the British and French fought at Quebec to see who would reign over this vast land.

headline: {u'main': u'DANONE TO PURCHASE SPARKLING SPRING WATER OF CANADA', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Groupe Danone, the bottler of Evian and Dannon water, agreed to buy Sparkling Spring Water Holdings of Canada for an undisclosed price to expand its home and office-delivery business in North America. The closely held Sparkling Spring has annual s...
lead_paragraph: Groupe Danone, the bottler of Evian and Dannon water, agreed to buy Sparkling Spring Water Holdings of Canada for an undisclosed price to expand its home and office-delivery business in North America. The closely held Sparkling Spring has annual sales of more than 100 million euros ($101 million). Outside of Canada, Sparkling Spring sells water in the United States, Britain and the Netherlands. Danone last month bought Patrimoine des Eaux du Québec. It also bought Chateaud'Eau International from Suez S.A. in October to enter the British market for home and office delivery.

headline: {u'main': u'Waves of Sewage and Auto Traffic Sweep Down on U.S. From Canada'}
snippet: The complaints from American officials sound familiar: pollution from an outdated sewage system fouling international waters, and a surge of people crossing the border, some of them illegally, in search of economic oppportunity.    Tijuana? El Pas...
lead_paragraph: The complaints from American officials sound familiar: pollution from an outdated sewage system fouling international waters, and a surge of people crossing the border, some of them illegally, in search of economic oppportunity. Tijuana? El Paso? Try the 49th Parallel, where Washington State meets British Columbia. In a rare display of friction, United States officials are upset over what they call a "1950's-era" approach to pollution control in Canada, and for gridlock at a border entry area that is now the most heavily traveled on the nation's northern boundary.

headline: {u'main': u'Free Trade in Fresh Water? Canada Says No and Halts Exports'}
snippet: For just about as long as there has been a border with the United States, some Canadians have believed that Americans covet their country and the resources it contains.     A few conspiracy subscribers still believe Washington harbors ambitions ab...
lead_paragraph: For just about as long as there has been a border with the United States, some Canadians have believed that Americans covet their country and the resources it contains. A few conspiracy subscribers still believe Washington harbors ambitions about northern expansion similar to those that provoked the first armed incursion into what is now Canada in the 18th century. And a certain type of Canadian is sure that free-trade agreements are a plot to make Canada a commercial colony of the United States.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA SEEKS ALLIES IN FIGHT ON ACID RAIN'}
snippet: Plastic Lake lay in stillness in this central Ontario region of heavy woods as a gentle shower fell from clouds that had picked up sulfuric pollutants from the smokestacks of the Ohio Valley.   Except for the drops bouncing on the clear surface, n...
lead_paragraph: Plastic Lake lay in stillness in this central Ontario region of heavy woods as a gentle shower fell from clouds that had picked up sulfuric pollutants from the smokestacks of the Ohio Valley. Except for the drops bouncing on the clear surface, nothing moved. There were no fish, no weeds, no crayfish. It was one of the thousands of dead or dying lakes of Canada.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA BLAMES ITSELF FOR HALF OF ITS ACID RAIN'}
snippet: A parliamentary subcommittee said today that half of the acid rain falling on Canada ''comes from domestic sources of air pollution.'' It recommended a number of actions within Canada to solve the problem.   Acid rain, which is precipitation made ...
lead_paragraph: A parliamentary subcommittee said today that half of the acid rain falling on Canada ''comes from domestic sources of air pollution.'' It recommended a number of actions within Canada to solve the problem. Acid rain, which is precipitation made more acidic than normal by emissions of sulfur and nitrogen oxides into the air, has become a major political irritant between the United States and Canada because of what is regarde d here as a lax attitude by the Federal and state governments a nd private industry in the United States.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA WEIGHS PROJECTS TO SELL WATER TO U.S.'}
snippet: After years of jealously guarding their water, Canadians, who possess more than one-fifth of the world's fresh, usable supplies, are beginning to consider projects to sell it to Americans.   ''On the whole I find more interest in the idea than opp...
lead_paragraph: After years of jealously guarding their water, Canadians, who possess more than one-fifth of the world's fresh, usable supplies, are beginning to consider projects to sell it to Americans. ''On the whole I find more interest in the idea than opposition,'' Robert Bourassa, leader of the Quebec Liberal Party, said in an interview here. Mr. Bourassa is backing at least the feasibility study of a $100 billion plan to turn James Bay into a freshwater lake by means of an enormous dike and then shipping the water south to the Great Lakes. From there it would be piped to arid western Canada and the southwestern United States.

headline: {u'main': u'Around the World; Senate Approves Treaty On Sea Border With Canada'}
snippet: The Senate voted 91 to 0 today to approve a treaty with Canada under which a panel of international judges would be asked to settle a dispute over maritime boundaries in the Gulf of Maine.   The treaty had originally been coupled with a United Sta...
lead_paragraph: The Senate voted 91 to 0 today to approve a treaty with Canada under which a panel of international judges would be asked to settle a dispute over maritime boundaries in the Gulf of Maine. The treaty had originally been coupled with a United States-Canadian fisheries treaty that had been bitterly opposed by New England senators who contended that it would injure American interests in the rich Georges Bank and Gulf of Maine fishing grounds.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Indians Sue on Mill', u'kicker': u'COMPANY NEWS'}
snippet: Two groups of Canadian Indians have filed a lawsuit in Toronto seeking $1.3 billion (Canadian) in damages from the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company for the pollution of rivers in their native territory in northern Ontario ...
lead_paragraph: Two groups of Canadian Indians have filed a lawsuit in Toronto seeking $1.3 billion (Canadian) in damages from the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company for the pollution of rivers in their native territory in northern Ontario around James Bay. The suit, which was filed on Monday by the Moose Factory First Nation and the New Post First Nation, charged that a 60 year-old paper mill in Kapuskasing owned by the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, a joint venture of the two American companies, had released dioxins and other dangerous substances into three rivers.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S.-Canada Seaway Tolls'}
snippet: The United States and Canada have agreed on new tolls that will be charged vessels traveling the St. Lawrence Seaway, beginning with the 1982 navigation season.   The changes, announced today by both countries, include an average 18 percent toll i...
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada have agreed on new tolls that will be charged vessels traveling the St. Lawrence Seaway, beginning with the 1982 navigation season. The changes, announced today by both countries, include an average 18 percent toll increase next year and another 10 percent in 1983 for vessels traveling the entire distance of the seaway.

headline: {u'main': u"U.S.-Canada Accord On Lakes' Pollution"}
snippet: The United States and Canada signed an agreement today on specific targets for reducing toxic chemical pollution of the Great Lakes, with a goal of eliminating certain toxic substances in the lakes within nine years.    Two years ago, President Cl...
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada signed an agreement today on specific targets for reducing toxic chemical pollution of the Great Lakes, with a goal of eliminating certain toxic substances in the lakes within nine years. Two years ago, President Clinton and Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada said the two countries would work toward eliminating the toxic pollutants in the Great Lakes.

lead_paragraph: Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, who heads the Senate Surface Transportation Committee, yesterday detailed his program for making $62.5-million of Federal funds available immediately to the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad. In an 1,800-word letter to his fellow Senators, Mr. Hartke warned that, unless Congress acted this month to provide the Penn Central with additional assistance, theoperation of its trains "can stop."

lead_paragraph: TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 25. -- Another boundary dispute has developed between Canada and the United States. This time it is a water boundary, the dispute being over the separation line running through Lake Erie. After seizure of American fishermen's nets for poaching in Canadian waters on Lake Erie, Secretary Schacht of the Keystone Fish Company, Erie, Penn., disputed the charge of trespass.

headline: {u'main': u'Low Water in Eastern Canada Promises Little Luck for Salmon Anglers', u'kicker': u'1'}

lead_paragraph: SALMON fishers who ordinarily look to the Miramichi for great September action apparently are out of luck this year because of extremely low water. Anglers who try the St. John, a larger river, may do some good, but the fact is that this has been a very bad year in all Eastern Canada streams, and there is no reason to believe that September will be any better.

lead_paragraph: The most important of the international speed-boat regattas on an American course during the season will be the Detroit meet of Sept. 3-6, for which an interesting entry list is already assured. Boats to start in various classes will include entries from France, England, Germany and Canada. Among the British there is a woman pilot, Miss Betty Carstairs, noted in England as the winner of many prizes.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The President's message on the Venezuelan matter was eagerly read in the State. War, and Navy Departments to-day when it appeared on the streets in the extra papers, of which it was a sole and sufficient feature. Little was known of the document or its purport, even in the State Department, where the correspondence which had been recently exchanged on the Venezuelan incident has been treasured with great care.

headline: {u'main': u'4TH REACTOR IS DOWN IN CANADA TORONTO, Oct. 31 (UPI) - The fourth nuclear reactor in two weeks was shut down in Canada today after a leak that released radioactive water into Lake Ontario, officials of Ontario Hydro said.'}
snippet: Officials said the No. 5 unit at the Pickering station near Toronto tripped off without explanation as technicians searched for the source of the leak in the 2,500 heat exchange coils that remove heat from the reactor.   It was the fourth nuclear ...
lead_paragraph: Officials said the No. 5 unit at the Pickering station near Toronto tripped off without explanation as technicians searched for the source of the leak in the 2,500 heat exchange coils that remove heat from the reactor. It was the fourth nuclear reactor incident in two weeks, following problems with reactors at the Bruce and Douglas Point stations on Lake Huron and at a small demonstration plant at Rolphton, Ont.

lead_paragraph: On the third successive day of wilting heat, which reached a maximum for the day of 91 at 12:10 P.M., sharp rain squalls drove the temperature down ten degrees in little more than a minute around 6 o'clock last evening and brought temporary relief to the city. Lightning accompanying it struck two houses in Woodmere, L.I., and a trolley car in Brooklyn, causing slight injuries to fourteen persons.

headline: {u'main': u'PRESERVE NIAGARA, HOOVER REQUESTS; President Seeks Action With Canada to Hold Scenic Beauty of Falls. ROCK SLIDE HASTENS MOVE Hope is Expressed at the White House That the Senate Will Ratify Border River Treaty. Board Had Considered Erosion. Would Test Withdrawal of Water.'}

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--As a result of the recent rockslide at Niagara Falls, which left an indentation 130 feet long and 40 feet deep on the American side, President Hoover directed Secretary Stimson and Secretary Hurley today to suggest to the Canadian Government a meeting of the Special International Niagara Board to plan measures for the preservation of the scenic beauties of the great cataract.

headline: {u'main': u'SWOLLEN RIVERS.; DAMAGE ALONG THE OTTAWA, IN CANADA AN UNPRECEDENTED OVERFLOW.', u'kicker': u'1'}
{u'main': u'World Briefing | Americas: Canada: 2 Sentenced In E. Coli Outbreak'}
snippet: Two brothers who were in charge of the water utility in Walkerton, Ontario, were sentenced for their roles in an E. coli outbreak four years ago that contaminated the town's water supply, killed seven people and made 2,500 others ill. Stan Koebel,...
lead_paragraph: Two brothers who were in charge of the water utility in Walkerton, Ontario, were sentenced for their roles in an E. coli outbreak four years ago that contaminated the town's water supply, killed seven people and made 2,500 others ill. Stan Koebel, who was manager of the utility in the town, 100 miles west of Toronto, was given a year in jail while his brother, Frank, the foreman, received nine months of house arrest. The judge noted that while neither man caused the outbreak -- a result of heavy rain and flooding that contaminated a well with manure from a nearby field -- both delayed disclosing problems even as residents fell ill. Colin Campbell (NYT)

lead_paragraph: TORONTO. COLD fresh-water lakes and rivers breed the best-flavored and gamiest of sport fish. Canada has nearly 200,000 square miles of fresh water, not including the Great Lakes. More than half that area has never been fished, and all of it is pure, cold water, alive with bass, trout, pike, muskellunge, pickerel, land-locked salmon and all the other fresh-water game fish for which anglers go hundreds of miles.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Rare Fish Poisoned'}
snippet: More than 400 tropical fish valued at $60,000, some rare and considered irreplaceable, were poisoned Wednesday at the Vancouver Public Aquarium, the officials said today. The curator, Gil Hewlett, said he suspected a copper sulphate compound had b...
lead_paragraph: More than 400 tropical fish valued at $60,000, some rare and considered irreplaceable, were poisoned Wednesday at the Vancouver Public Aquarium, the officials said today. The curator, Gil Hewlett, said he suspected a copper sulphate compound had been dumped into the water supply. The affected tank contained about 15 percent of the Aquarium exhibits, and fewer than 2 percent survived.

snippet: The commissioner of the environment, Johanne Gélinas, said in a report that the country's drinking water, national parks and oceans were not being adequately protected. The report by Ms. Gélinas, who oversees environmental matters for the audito...
lead_paragraph: The commissioner of the environment, Johanne Gélinas, said in a report that the country's drinking water, national parks and oceans were not being adequately protected. The report by Ms. Gélinas, who oversees environmental matters for the auditor general, said the government, which has often pledged to make the environment a priority, ''suffers from a chronic inability to see its own initiatives to completion.'' In response, the environment minister, Stéphane Dion, acknowledged that the government could do more. Colin Campbell (NYT)

headline: {u'main': u'Tower Collapses in Canada', u'print_headline': u'Tower Collapses In Canada', u'content_kicker': u'Sports Briefing | Skiing'}
snippet: Water seeping into a gondola tower, then freezing in extreme cold, caused a tower to rupture and collapse this week, injuring a dozen skiers at Canada’s Whistler resort, officials said. The gondola cabins remained on the line after the tower col...
lead_paragraph: Water seeping into a gondola tower, then freezing in extreme cold, caused a tower to rupture and collapse this week, injuring a dozen skiers at Canada’s Whistler resort, officials said. The gondola cabins remained on the line after the tower collapsed Tuesday afternoon, but several of them dropped more than 30 feet as the span sagged, and two hit the ground. Fifty-three people were stranded on the line for up for up to three and a half hours as rescue crews worked to get them down using ropes, ladders and fire trucks. A dozen people were treated for minor injuries — from bruises to a fractured vertebrae.

{u'main': u'World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Ontario Premier Resigning'}
snippet: The Ontario premier, Mike Harris, announced plans to resign as leader of Canada's largest province and head of the provincial Progressive Conservative party. Elected in 1995 and 1999, Mr. Harris, 57, led Ontario's Common Sense Revolution, a right-...
lead_paragraph: The Ontario premier, Mike Harris, announced plans to resign as leader of Canada's largest province and head of the provincial Progressive Conservative party. Elected in 1995 and 1999, Mr. Harris, 57, led Ontario's Common Sense Revolution, a right-wing platform of tax cuts, privatization and sweeping changes in education, welfare and health care. In recent months, Mr. Harris has been accused of covering up his role in the death of a protester shot by provincial police in 1995 and of instituting cutbacks that contributed to a public health scandal in which seven residents of Walkerton, Ontario, died from drinking water tainted by E. coli bacteria. Susan Catto (NYT)

snippet: Canadian soft drink manufacturers, including the local units of Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, said they would withdraw carbonated drinks from vending machines at elementary and junior high schools in the country by the start of the next school year. The ...
lead_paragraph: Canadian soft drink manufacturers, including the local units of Coca-Cola and PepsiCo, said they would withdraw carbonated drinks from vending machines at elementary and junior high schools in the country by the start of the next school year. The move follows pressure from politicians, educators and parents seeking healthier food choices for children. Half the beverages stocked in the schools will be water and pure fruit juice, while noncarbonated juice and sports drinks will make up the rest. High school students will still be able to buy carbonated soft drinks. Bernard Simon (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Looking down the steep bank from the dirt road about 150 yards above Little Indian pool on the St. Jean River, Bill Taylor, a fishing buddy as well as the president of the Atlantic Salmon Federation, remarked: "Look at all those dark shapes. I'm sure some of them are salmon." "I believe all of them are salmon," our guide, Austin Clark, said. "At least they were salmon yesterday."

headline: {u'main': u'ELECTRICITY GETS CHEAPER IN CANADA; Price of Current for House Lighting Is Nearly One-third Less Than in 1913.'}

Furthermore, the bulletin points out, this single item is still annually declining in cost.

lead_paragraph: Yielding to the protests of shipping interests in New York, Boston, Baltimore, and Philadelphia, and committees of the Chamber of Commerce and other public bodies here, the Trunk Lines Association, at a meeting here yesterday, decided to reduce the rates on grain from the Great Lakes to New York to meet the "foreign water" competition which last year gave Montreal and other Canadian ports practically all of the wheat-carrying trade to Europe.

lead_paragraph: LONDON, Ontario, July 9.--A terrific thunder and rain storm passed over the city this evening. The rain fell in torrents, accompanied by very high wind. Much damage has been done to the trees and fences, and it is feared the grain throughout this section of country will be badly damaged.

headline: {u'main': u'Canada Reaches Oil Agreements'}
snippet: The Canadian federal Government concluded oil exploration agreements worth $263 million (in Canadian currency) under which Shell Canada Resources Ltd. would drill six deep-water wells along the Scotian Shelf, Energy Minister Marc Lalonde announced...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian federal Government concluded oil exploration agreements worth $263 million (in Canadian currency) under which Shell Canada Resources Ltd. would drill six deep-water wells along the Scotian Shelf, Energy Minister Marc Lalonde announced. The accord is the first signed under the energy exploration regime agreed on by Nova Scotia province and the federal Government. Mr. Lalonde said that when the full interests in farm-out agreements had been earned, the present Canadian ownership rate should rise to 29.6 percent from its present 6.28 percent. When those arrangements are completed, he said, the working interest on most of the blocks covered in the agreements should be Shell Canada Resources, 50 percent; Shell Explorer Ltd., 25 percent; Canterra Energy Ltd., 12.5 percent; and Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., 12.5 percent.

headline: {u'main': u'Plane From J.F.K. Crashes Off Canada'}
snippet: A Swissair plane carrying 227 passengers and crew crashed late last night south of Halifax, Nova Scotia, while on a flight from Kennedy International Airport to Switzerland, Federal officials said.    Eyewitnesses and early reports indicated that ...
lead_paragraph: A Swissair plane carrying 227 passengers and crew crashed late last night south of Halifax, Nova Scotia, while on a flight from Kennedy International Airport to Switzerland, Federal officials said. Eyewitnesses and early reports indicated that the plane had crashed in the Atlantic Ocean, seven miles off the coast and 40 miles south of Halifax. There were conflicting reports about survivors. Two Halifax newspapers quoted rescue officials as saying that bodies were pulled from the water, debris and oil slicks had been spotted in the cold, dark waters, and that an overpowering smell of jet fuel lingered in the air.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA RED-FACED ON NUCLEAR LEAK'}
snippet: Just as the Canadian Government announced this month that it had sold one of its heavy-water nuclear power plants to Rumania, one of its reactors in use developed an unprecedented leak.   The accident in Pickering, Ontario, never threatened public...
lead_paragraph: Just as the Canadian Government announced this month that it had sold one of its heavy-water nuclear power plants to Rumania, one of its reactors in use developed an unprecedented leak. The accident in Pickering, Ontario, never threatened public safety, but it forced a costly shutdown of the power plant and increased criticism of the Government's interest in exporting the reactors to sustain Canada's nuclear industry, which has 35,000 workers. ''The most likely casualty from the accident will be the Government's efforts to export these reactors,'' said Norman Rubin, a spokesman for Energy Probe, a Toronto-based citizens action group that monitors and comments on Government energy policies and programs. The group contends that in its zeal to sell the reactors, the Government has been concentrating on developing countries that are unlikely or unable to apply full safeguards. In general, the group would like the Government to follow the lead of major private companies in the United States that are phasing out reactor construction while stressing projects in nuclear waste conversion and disposal.

headline: {u'main': u'All in This Together: A Family, a Small Boat, A Long Trip to Canada', u'kicker': u'JOURNEYS'}
snippet: THINGS had gone beautifully. We were coming into Chelsea Piers after a 12-day journey through New York's waterways, bringing our 30-foot wooden fishing boat into a graceful curve, successfully throwing the dockmaster our bow line. But then a heavy...
lead_paragraph: THINGS had gone beautifully. We were coming into Chelsea Piers after a 12-day journey through New York's waterways, bringing our 30-foot wooden fishing boat into a graceful curve, successfully throwing the dockmaster our bow line. But then a heavy current carried us starboard. ''Watch out!'' all four of us on board seemed to yell simultaneously. And instead of slipping nicely into our berth, we crashed into the dock, causing the feet of the unfortunate dockmaster to slide right out from under him. Earlier this summer, my husband, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney; myself; and our children, Joshua, 19, and Amy, 12, had decided to fulfill a longstanding fantasy -- to take our 1962 bass boat, Souvenir, up the Hudson River, through the Champlain Canal, into Lake Champlain, and on up to Montreal via the Richelieu River. It would be the longest boat trip we had ever taken together, and we wondered whether we would still be speaking when it ended.

headline: {u'main': u'SURRENDERING TO THE RAPIDS IN CANADA'}
snippet: The Ottawa River rolled gently through thick woodland and at least one of the 11 people on the rubber raft Wanton Willy was feeling somewhat silly about the life jacket and hockey helmet that had been issued each member of the paying crew. A murmu...
lead_paragraph: The Ottawa River rolled gently through thick woodland and at least one of the 11 people on the rubber raft Wanton Willy was feeling somewhat silly about the life jacket and hockey helmet that had been issued each member of the paying crew. A murmuring current propelled the raft downstream off Calumet Island, at a point some 60 miles west of Ottawa. Blue herons waded in the wide river. The sun shone brightly. The Wanton Willy was the only boat in sight and the greatest danger at that point had come from the mosquitoes and the black flies that had been left behind when the river widened. MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN is chief of the Ottawa bureau of The Times.Then, after the raft had been moving for about an hour, propelled by the lazy strokes of the dilettante adventurers, the point of the life jackets and helmets was suddenly made clear: first by the roar of water and then by the sight of a turbulent cascade. The craft was pulled up to shore and the passengers who had paid to spend the day running the Rocher Fendu Rapids walked along a narrow path to inspect the first of five flumes through which they and the raft would try to navigate in a four-and-a-half-hour trip downriver.

headline: {u'main': u'Huge Ice Shelf Is Reported To Break Up In Canada'}
snippet: A large ice shelf that has jutted into the Arctic Ocean from northernmost Canada for at least 3,000 years has broken up over the last two years, providing fresh evidence that the region is warming past thresholds that can produce abrupt changes, s...
lead_paragraph: A large ice shelf that has jutted into the Arctic Ocean from northernmost Canada for at least 3,000 years has broken up over the last two years, providing fresh evidence that the region is warming past thresholds that can produce abrupt changes, scientists said yesterday. The scientists, from Laval University in Quebec and the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, described the changes in a paper published in the Geophysical Research Letters.

headline: {u'main': u'World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Native Groups Win Land Ruling'}
snippet: In a decision that may complicate logging, mining and other natural resource projects, the Supreme Court of Canada said that governments must consult native groups before allowing major changes on land involved in ownership disputes. The decision ...
lead_paragraph: In a decision that may complicate logging, mining and other natural resource projects, the Supreme Court of Canada said that governments must consult native groups before allowing major changes on land involved in ownership disputes. The decision came out of a case started by the Haida Indians after the province of British Columbia transferred a logging license covering about 25 percent of the Queen Charlotte Islands to the Weyerhaeuser Company of Federal Way, Wash. Those islands and the water surrounding them have been the focus of a century-old ownership claim by the Haida. Much of Canada's resource activity, like Weyerhaeuser's logging, takes place on land owned by provinces. In its unanimous decision, the court said that only governments, not users like Weyerhaeuser, must consult aboriginal groups. While it did not spell out the nature of those consultations, the court turned down a similar appeal yesterday by another native group in British Columbia opposed to the reopening of a mining road. In that case the court found that making the native group part of an environmental review was enough. Ian Austen (NYT)

{u'main': u'STYROFOAM SWANS VS. CANADA GEESE'}
snippet: WHENEVER a flock of Canada geese approaches the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich, usually from over Long Island Sound, Patrick Lucas shades his eyes with his hand. He watches the birds dip their wings as they descend for a closer look at the...
lead_paragraph: WHENEVER a flock of Canada geese approaches the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich, usually from over Long Island Sound, Patrick Lucas shades his eyes with his hand. He watches the birds dip their wings as they descend for a closer look at the four-acre lake on the course. Then a satisfied smile crosses his face as he sees the waterfowl regain altitude and resume their flight. Mr. Lucas, superintendent of the Innis Arden course, offers two reasons for the lack of interest by Canada geese in the neatly landscaped lake. First, he has placed small families of artificial swans on the water and second, other waterfowl such as ducks and egrets are absent.

{u'main': u'STYROFOAM SWANS VS. CANADA GEESE'}
snippet: WHENEVER a flock of Canada geese approaches the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich, usually from over Long Island Sound, Patrick Lucas shades his eyes with his hand. He watches the birds dip their wings as they descend for a closer look at the...
lead_paragraph: WHENEVER a flock of Canada geese approaches the Innis Arden Golf Club in Old Greenwich, usually from over Long Island Sound, Patrick Lucas shades his eyes with his hand. He watches the birds dip their wings as they descend for a closer look at the four-acre lake on the course. Then a satisfied smile crosses his face as he sees the waterfowl regain altitude and resume their flight. Mr. Lucas, superintendent of the Innis Arden course, offers two reasons for the lack of interest by Canada geese in the neatly landscaped lake. First, he has placed small families of artificial swans on the water and second, other waterfowl such as ducks and egrets are absent.

lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D., July 30 -- A call has been issued by a committee of twelve, appointed by the Grand Forts Chamber of Commerce for a Canadian-United States Reciprocity Conference, to meet at Grand Forks, on Sept. 1 and 2 next. headline: {u'main': u'U.S. and Canada Reach Deal on Draining Lake'}
snippet: The agreement overcomes pollution concerns that had become an escalating diplomatic irritant for more than a year....
lead_paragraph: American and Canadian negotiators have reached an agreement that will allow North Dakota to drain excess water from its largest natural lake into Canadian lakes and rivers, overcoming pollution concerns that had become an escalating diplomatic irritant for more than a year. Devils Lake, in northeast North Dakota, has not drained into the Red River basin for more than 1,000 years, leading to fears by Canadian officials that mixing waters could introduce striped bass and microscopic species into Canadian waters, particularly Lake Winnipeg. Lake Winnipeg has no natural predators for unforeseen species, Canada has argued, and the diversion could spoil a fishing industry that generates $20 million a year in income.

headline: {u'main': u'In Canada, a Resort Town by a Bay'}
snippet: A NEW BRUNSWICK transportation official once told me almost wistfully that he lived in the ''drive-through province.'' I would have heartily agreed --  the hours I've logged on New Brunswick highways on my way to Prince Edward Island each summer t...
lead_paragraph: A NEW BRUNSWICK transportation official once told me almost wistfully that he lived in the ''drive-through province.'' I would have heartily agreed -- the hours I've logged on New Brunswick highways on my way to Prince Edward Island each summer tended to confirm the joke -- except for our memorable stays in St. Andrews. St. Andrews, officially known as St. Andrews-by-the-Sea, is a lovely coastal hamlet just off Highway 1, near the Maine border, with architectural charm, choice inns, good restaurants and a spectacular view of the Passamaquoddy Bay (part of the Bay of Fundy). It was recognized as a Canadian National Historic District last year, and is a wonderful place to stop with children, even if it's only for ice cream and a stroll.

lead_paragraph: LEAD: AT 5:30 one April morning, distracted by honking and the sound of wings flapping on water, I pulled up the shade. Our resident mallards, Figaro and Susanna, who had arrived on schedule weeks ago, were floating on the sidelines of the pond, still as decoys. Their eyes were focused on two great Canada geese, the size of floor pillows, who had landed on the water and were cruising, necks held aloft, with an air of satisfaction.

headline: {u'main': u'Little Buffalo Journal;In a Poisoned Forest, A Tribe Canada Forgot'}
snippet: He shot and killed a fat bull moose last spring, his first moose in more than two years. Its antlers crown the tawny roof of the log cabin that Joel Laboucan  built in happier days, before hundreds of oil jacks, a sour gas processing plant with th...
lead_paragraph: He shot and killed a fat bull moose last spring, his first moose in more than two years. Its antlers crown the tawny roof of the log cabin that Joel Laboucan built in happier days, before hundreds of oil jacks, a sour gas processing plant with the smell of rotten eggs and clear-cut logging scarred the land and scared off the wildlife. Mr. Laboucan, 62, is a hunter and trapper who has lived all his adult life in this small, isolated Lubicon Cree community 350 miles north of Edmonton.

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada announced today that his Government had secured concessions from the United States on the North American Free Trade Agreement and was prepared to drop his opposition to the pact coming into force on Jan. 1. The announcement removed a last uncertainty about the institution of the three-country accord, which would eliminate most duties and investment barriers within the United States, Canada and Mexico over the next 15 years.

headline: {u'main': u'Where Elbows Rarely Rub in Canada'}
snippet: SEAL RIVER, Que. In the pocket formed by the swooping northern coastline of Ontario and Quebec provinces lies James Bay. In geog  raphy and history books, it plays second fiddle to the much longer and wider Hudson Bay, which flares out just above....
lead_paragraph: SEAL RIVER, Que. In the pocket formed by the swooping northern coastline of Ontario and Quebec provinces lies James Bay. In geog raphy and history books, it plays second fiddle to the much longer and wider Hudson Bay, which flares out just above. This suits fishermen fine. They fly in from all over to fish around James for trout and pike, happy to find a region where elbows rarely rub.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Jan. 15. -- A Canadian corporation may be used to operate the steamship lines now controlled by the New Haven Railroad as a means of complying with the new law forbidding railroads to own steamship lines. This corporation is already in existence. It is the Boston and Yarmouth Steamship Company, Ltd., of Montreal, and it has just taken over the Yarmouth division of the Eastern Steamship Company, formerly the Dominion Atlantic Line.

headline: {u'main': u'Arctic Shortcut for Shipping Raises New Fears in Canada'}
snippet: In this Arctic village, beachfront real estate means a summer view of polar sea ice glinting a few miles offshore.    But last summer, Inuvialuit natives here on the northern edge of Canada had front-row seats for unusual open-water traffic -- a C...
lead_paragraph: In this Arctic village, beachfront real estate means a summer view of polar sea ice glinting a few miles offshore. But last summer, Inuvialuit natives here on the northern edge of Canada had front-row seats for unusual open-water traffic -- a Chinese research vessel examining ice conditions, a Russian boat towing a huge drydock from Siberia and an American cruise ship navigating the once forbidden Northwest Passage.

headline: {u'main': u'ANCIENT CULTURE TRACED IN ARCTIC; Relics Found in Northeastern Canada Show Village Life at Least 3,000 Years Ago'}

headline: {u'main': u"SLAYERS' HAUNTS SEARCHED; Belief Waning That Trolley Hold-Up Men Fled to Canada."}
snippet: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 23. -- Belief that the bandits who shot and killed two employes of the Westchester Electric Railroad Company early Monday morning, in an effort to rob them of $1,800 in receipts, may have fled to Canada, is waning, accordi...
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 23. -- Belief that the bandits who shot and killed two employes of the Westchester Electric Railroad Company early Monday morning, in an effort to rob them of $1,800 in receipts, may have fled to Canada, is waning, according to the Mount Vernon police, who admitted that the search was being directed toward the Bronx, where the fugitives are known to have had many friends.

headline: {u'main': u'NOTHING LEFT BUT BASS; NEARLY ALL THE NEIGHBORING FISHING GROUNDS DESERTED. ANGLING IN AND ABOUT HELL GATE -- THE TROUT SEASON IN CANADA -- DUCK SHOOTING WILL Be GOOD.'}
snippet: Fishermen have now only the striped bass left to practice their favorite sport upon, but the game, such as it is, is abundant and vigorous enough to make up for the departure of the other species. The storm of a week ago proved the signal for the ...
lead_paragraph: Fishermen have now only the striped bass left to practice their favorite sport upon, but the game, such as it is, is abundant and vigorous enough to make up for the departure of the other species. The storm of a week ago proved the signal for the blue and weak fish to turn their noses toward the deep water, while the recent northeaster has driven out even the last stragglers.

headline: {u'main': u'ACID RAIN STUDIES LAPSE IN CANADA'}
snippet: At a time when the Canadian Government has been sharply critical of what it regards as United States inaction on curbing acid rain, it appears to be letting several major research efforts of its own lapse.    For the fiscal year beginning Sunday, ...
lead_paragraph: At a time when the Canadian Government has been sharply critical of what it regards as United States inaction on curbing acid rain, it appears to be letting several major research efforts of its own lapse. For the fiscal year beginning Sunday, the Government has not set aside money for research on acid rain's effects on human health, or provided for more research on how lakes and other bodies of water become acidified. These actions could be reversed later in the year, and appear to be the responses of particular agencies to fiscal pressures, more than policy shifts. But Canadian environmentalists have expressed concern that their Government's efforts to persuade Washington to do more to reduce acid rain might be hampered by the decisions.

headline: {u'main': u'OUTDOORS: SALMON IN CANADA', u'kicker': u'OUTDOORS'}
snippet: DAWSONVILLE, New Brunswick    Dusk came swiftly in the narrow, twisting valley of the Upsalquitch, hastened by an exhalation of mist from the river's surface, mist that at first reached no higher than a man's head but later rose and thickened unti...
lead_paragraph: DAWSONVILLE, New Brunswick Dusk came swiftly in the narrow, twisting valley of the Upsalquitch, hastened by an exhalation of mist from the river's surface, mist that at first reached no higher than a man's head but later rose and thickened until only the tops of the cathedral spruces on the far shore could be seen. Parr, young salmon not much longer than a man's finger, rose for midges and sometimes seized the fly with which I was fishing for their larger brethren. Thrice, in the 40 minutes my guide Dennis Moran and I were at Four-Mile Island Pool, mature salmon burst from the dark, gliding water, celebrating, I liked to think, the end of a three-year journey of several thousand miles in the North Atlantic, returning at last to their natal stream.

lead_paragraph: MONTREAL, Quebec, May 27. -- The first of the English-built boats to race for the Canada Cup arrived here to-day on board the steamship Montford from Bristol. She is the yacht designed by A.E. Payne for Cawthra Mulock of Toronto, and was built by Summers Payne at Southampton. headline: {u'main': u'NUCLEAR POWER FROM CANADA MAY FILL NEW ENGLAND NEED'}
snippet: As the Seabrook 1 nuclear power plant sits dormant on the New Hampshire coast, three-quarters complete but on the brink of cancellation because of cost overruns, New England utilities are shopping here for alternative power.    The Canadians say t...
lead_paragraph: As the Seabrook 1 nuclear power plant sits dormant on the New Hampshire coast, three-quarters complete but on the brink of cancellation because of cost overruns, New England utilities are shopping here for alternative power. The Canadians say they are willing to provide it by what they see as the most economical and reliable means: nuclear power. The New Brunswick Electric Power Commission says it is prepared to build a nuclear plant whose entire output would be sold to New England utilities for 20 years at slightly more than the cost of production. ''I think we can be competitive in the market, supplying power under terms and conditions acceptable to purchasing utilities,'' said Richard Cote, general manager of Maritime Nuclear, a joint venture of New Brunswick Power and Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., the federally owned reactor-building concern. Meeting the U.S. Market ''In the future, you wouldn't have to stretch the case too far to say you could build units in the Maritimes to meet the market in the U.S.,'' Mr. Cote said in an interview at his office here.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- By a Canadian Government order just issued American fishing vessels after Dec. 31 will be unable to enter Canadian harbors except in emergency. headline: {u'main': u'PROVINCES GET PUBLIC LANDS; Canada Surrenders Domain to Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba.'}
snippet: OTTAWA, Ontario., Aug. 10. -- Negotiations are in progress between the Dominion Government and the Governments of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba for the surrender to these Provinces of the public domain, exclusive of colonization lands, hithe...
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Ontario., Aug. 10. -- Negotiations are in progress between the Dominion Government and the Governments of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba for the surrender to these Provinces of the public domain, exclusive of colonization lands, hitherto absolutely controlled by the Federal authorities. This transfer of the natural resources is of the utmost importance to the Western provinces, and goes far toward the removal of a standing grievance between the Federal and provincial authorities.

headline: {u'main': u'NEW PLAN TO SAVE NIAGARA.; Senator Brown Would Like a Treaty with Canada to Protect the Falls.'}

lead_paragraph: ALBANY, March 15. -- A new move to preserve Niagara Falls from the injury which it is feared will be wrought if the Thompson bill be enacted was made to-day in the Senate by Senator E.R. Brown, who introduced a concurrent resolution memorializing Congress to negotiate a treaty with the Dominion of Canada to prevent the diversion of the waters of the Niagara River and the destruction of the cataract.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA SETS RECORD IN NEWSPRINT OUTPUT; Production in March and First Quarter Unprecedented -- 18% Gain Over 1935.'}
snippet: MONTREAL, April 14. -- With output of newsprint paper by Canadian mills last month setting a new all-time record for March, production for the first quarter of 1936 reached a total of 693,424 tons, by far the largest volume for any quarter in the ...
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL, April 14. -- With output of newsprint paper by Canadian mills last month setting a new all-time record for March, production for the first quarter of 1936 reached a total of 693,424 tons, by far the largest volume for any quarter in the Canadian industry's history and an increase of nearly 18 per cent over production in the first quarter of 1935.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA CRUISER SAFE AFTER GOING ON ROCK; Niobe, Flagship of Dominion Navy, Struck in Fog Off Cape Sable -- No Lives Lost.'}
snippet: HALIFAX, N.S., July 30. -- With the plates on her starboard side badly damaged, much water in her hold, her starboard engine out of commission, and her pumps working overtime to keep her afloat -- the result of running ashore early to-day -- the C...
lead_paragraph: HALIFAX, N.S., July 30. -- With the plates on her starboard side badly damaged, much water in her hold, her starboard engine out of commission, and her pumps working overtime to keep her afloat -- the result of running ashore early to-day -- the Canadian cruiser Niobe, flagship of the Canadian Navy, is lying at anchor off the Southwest Whistling Buoy, near Cape Sable, waiting for the fog to lift before proceeding to Halifax.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK. A campaign waged a half century ago to rid American publishing of the burden of tariffs on newsprint has been rewarded by the "phenomenal" growth of a strong United States press, the Newsprint Information Committee states in its publication, Newsprint Facts, published yesterday. The committee is composed of a group of Canadian newsprint producers.

headline: {u'main': u'In Canada, Stealing Time For Renewal', u'kicker': u'SPAS AND SPORTS'}
snippet: THE songwriter makes a good case about the difference a day makes. But does it really? The problem was that my daughter Hannah and I literally had only 24 little hours. She had traveled to eastern Ontario for a medical school interview, where I ha...
lead_paragraph: THE songwriter makes a good case about the difference a day makes. But does it really? The problem was that my daughter Hannah and I literally had only 24 little hours. She had traveled to eastern Ontario for a medical school interview, where I had accompanied her; now she was flying back to the west coast to finish her exams. In between there was a window of opportunity called Ste. Anne's, a country inn and spa in the rolling hills of Northumberland County, an hour and a quarter east of Toronto. Hoping that country air, a full range of spa services, three fine meals and a night in a four-poster bed would reinvigorate us for the fray, we turned off Highway 401 at Grafton and headed north. Ste. Anne's itself is no stranger to reinvigoration, having had several identities without entirely shedding the earlier selves. As a result, the place is full of mixed messages, none unpleasant and some decidedly piquant. The first is the look of the building itself, like an Ontario farmhouse that tried to grow up and become a castle. At the center sits a plain-Jane front-gabled house with stone walls almost two feet thick, built in 1857 by a farmer named Samuel Massey; flanking it are the wings, bays, turrets, arches and other fieldstone fantasies concocted by a Texas oil baron and baroness who bought the farm in 1939.

headline: {u'main': u'RARE SHEEP AND ELK BAGGED IN CANADA; Black-Tailed White Type Are Among 200 Specimens Taken by Snyder Expedition.'}

lead_paragraph: The Snyder Canadian Expedition, which has just completed the most extensive scientific expedition ever to go into Northwestern Canada, obtained more than 200 specimens of mammals, among them being the first specimens of black-tailed white sheep and elk to come out of the North, said George G. Goodwin, a member of the expedition, in an interview yesterday afternoon in the American Museum of Natural History, where he is assistant curator of mammals.

headline: {u'main': u'MINING AREA WAITS ON BETTER ACCESS; Transportation to Great Bear Field in Canada Urged by Securities Commissioner.'}
snippet: TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 14. -- Solution of the mining riddle of the Canadian Northwest, which is transportation, can be hastened materially by a small expenditure on the Great Bear River and on the purchase of boats, and such steps will open another a...
lead_paragraph: TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 14. -- Solution of the mining riddle of the Canadian Northwest, which is transportation, can be hastened materially by a small expenditure on the Great Bear River and on the purchase of boats, and such steps will open another area promising to add much to the prosperity of the Dominion, Colonel George A. Drew. chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, told the Empire Club of Canada here this week.

headline: {u'main': u'Woods Finds the Going Tough in Canada, Again', u'kicker': u'GOLF'}
snippet: For some reason, when Tiger Woods has traveled north to Canada, his performance has headed south.    Three years ago, Woods missed the cut at the Bell Canadian Open, the only time in 86 career starts on the PGA Tour as a professional that Woods ha...
lead_paragraph: For some reason, when Tiger Woods has traveled north to Canada, his performance has headed south. Three years ago, Woods missed the cut at the Bell Canadian Open, the only time in 86 career starts on the PGA Tour as a professional that Woods has missed a cut. Today, Woods returned to the Canadian Open for the first time since 1997, trying to accomplish a rare triple crown. Lee Trevino is the only player to win the United States Open, the British Open and the Canadian Open in the same year (1971), and after waltzing to victories at both the United States and British Opens, Woods arrived in the suburbs of Toronto this week hoping to add even more luster to his history-making season.

headline: {u'main': u"GOINGS-ON IN CANADA; Tourists Will Be Able to Eavesdrop on Their Neighbors' Election Campaign", u'kicker': u'1'}
snippet: TORONTO -- Vacationists from the United States this spring and summer will find Canada preparing for a national election, and thus will be able to observe how their northern neighbors conduct a political campaign. They will also find a number of n...
lead_paragraph: TORONTO -- Vacationists from the United States this spring and summer will find Canada preparing for a national election, and thus will be able to observe how their northern neighbors conduct a political campaign. They will also find a number of new roads, built since last year, and less-crowded conditions at hotels and resorts.

headline: {u'main': u'Tracks From a Primordial Sea Are Found in Canada'}
snippet: Scientists investigating an abandoned quarry in Canada have found what appear to be the oldest known footprints of terrestrial creatures -- footlong critters resembling modern bugs that crawled from the sea onto land and left tracks in sandy dunes...
lead_paragraph: Scientists investigating an abandoned quarry in Canada have found what appear to be the oldest known footprints of terrestrial creatures -- footlong critters resembling modern bugs that crawled from the sea onto land and left tracks in sandy dunes. The sandstone is 480 million to 500 million years old. Scientists believe the discovery region -- just north of Lake Ontario outside Kingston, Ontario -- was a sandy beach on a primordial sea.

headline: {u'main': u'CLOSE MONITORING IN U.S. AND CANADA', u'kicker': u'NUCLEAR DISASTER: THE CONSEQUENCES'}
snippet: The United States and Canada took steps yesterday to provide early warning of any increase in North American atmospheric radioactivity resulting from the Soviet nuclear accident.   In Washington, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency sa...
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada took steps yesterday to provide early warning of any increase in North American atmospheric radioactivity resulting from the Soviet nuclear accident. In Washington, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said it began checking its national network of radiation monitoring stations daily instead of the usual twice a week, In Canada, the Department of Health and Welfare has also begun daily monitoring instead of the usual weekly monitoring. Bliss Tracy, a spokesman, said, ''The fact that radiation was detected in Scandinavia would lead us to believe enough is there so that some will reach Canada.'' But he added that the level of contamination was not considered likely to rise high enough to warrant protective action.

snippet: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 29. -- The Senate Committee on Fish and Game will leave New-York the evening of Aug. 15 for Watertown, from which place they will go to Toronto, and from there probably to Ottawa, Montreal, and Quebec, for the purpose of c...
lead_paragraph: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 29. -- The Senate Committee on Fish and Game will leave New-York the evening of Aug. 15 for Watertown, from which place they will go to Toronto, and from there probably to Ottawa, Montreal, and Quebec, for the purpose of conferring with the Commissioners of Fisheries of Canada, to perfect an amicable arrangement which will operate as a protection to the fish which abound in the waters lying between the two countries.

headline: {u'main': u'Hollinger Sheds Its Last Assets In Canada'}
snippet: Hollinger International, once the dominant newspaper group in Canada, has shed the last of its Canadian publications....
lead_paragraph: Hollinger International, once the dominant newspaper group in Canada, has shed the last of its Canadian publications, among them the newspaper where Conrad M. Black first entered publishing. In a statement to Canadian securities regulators, Hollinger said it had agreed to sell its remaining Canadian properties -- 25 small newspapers in British Columbia, two in Quebec and an assortment of trade publications -- for 121.7 million Canadian dollars ($105 million) to Glacier Ventures International of Vancouver, British Columbia, a bottled water company turned publisher. The statement was released late Wednesday.

snippet: One hundred and fifty-two people found crammed into two lifeboats off Newfoundland were identified today as Sri Lankans who had apparently paid thousands of dollars to be brought by freighter to the shores of Canada.   They were picked up Monday b...
lead_paragraph: One hundred and fifty-two people found crammed into two lifeboats off Newfoundland were identified today as Sri Lankans who had apparently paid thousands of dollars to be brought by freighter to the shores of Canada. They were picked up Monday by three Canadian fishing boats. Despite what the Sri Lankans described as five days of drifting about the North Atlantic in the lifeboats, the authorities said their health and spirits appeared good. Only one man was admitted to a local hospital.

headline: {u'main': u'OUTDOORSNelson Bryant Salmon in Canada A Bitter Harvest'}
snippet: CANADA and its Maritime Provinces continue to agonize over how to apportion fairly the country's harvest of Atlantic salmon among sport and commercial fishermen and a subsistence fishery by native Indians, while maintaining viable populations of o...
lead_paragraph: CANADA and its Maritime Provinces continue to agonize over how to apportion fairly the country's harvest of Atlantic salmon among sport and commercial fishermen and a subsistence fishery by native Indians, while maintaining viable populations of one of the world's most highly prized food and game fishes. With the exception of a few rivers, this year's Atlantic salmon angling in Canada has ranged from fair to terrible. A prolonged drought and low water in the species' spawning streams are partly to blame. Low water also kept salmon milling about in or near the mouths of those rivers, where in some instances they were illegally overharvested by commercial netters. In the Province of New Brunswick, such a situation triggered a public meeting of the New Brunswick Council of the Atlantic Salmon Federation (A.S.F.). The resulting outcry over the salmon's plight generated a great deal of attention in Canada's press.

lead_paragraph: A voice from on high came to me as I stood thigh-deep in the Upsalquitch River casting a fly to Atlantic salmon: ''Try that again. One of them moved.'' The advice was from my guide, Gerry Thomas, who was perched behind me in a tree stand on the edge of the forest. From that vantage point he could see several salmon resting in Caribou Pool.

headline: {u'main': u'Dam in Canada Could Endanger Shad', u'kicker': u'OUTDOORS'}
snippet: WILL a power project in Canada's Bay of Fundy affect the future of East Coast fishing as far south as Florida? As farfetched as that question at first may seem, both Canadian and American scientists say the concern is warranted, for though it woul...
lead_paragraph: WILL a power project in Canada's Bay of Fundy affect the future of East Coast fishing as far south as Florida? As farfetched as that question at first may seem, both Canadian and American scientists say the concern is warranted, for though it would produce virtually pollution-free energy, the environmental costs of harnessing the Fundy tides of more than 50 feet may be too high. Most of those costs, due to the effects of a Fundy dam on tides in the Gulf of Maine, would be borne not by Canada, but by the United States, and would range from the flooding of valuable New England beachfront property to damage to coastal anadromous fish stocks, especially the herrings, most especially the American shad. While fishermen in the Northeast are just looking forward to the spring shad-spawning runs in the Delaware, Hudson, and Connecticut Rivers, in southern rivers the shad season has been under way since mid-February. In the St. John's in Florida, the Altemaha in Georgia, Albemarle Sound to Virginia's Rappahannock and Potomac, the traditional shad fisheries are commercial fisheries. There, gill nets take the large silver-sided herrings; most of the fish is sold for its roe.

lead_paragraph: The Cunard liner Mauretania sped 180 miles out of her course yesterday in response to an SOS from the British freighter Laleham, which had wirelessed that she was sinking, with twenty-eight men aboard, 400 miles southeast of Halifax. But when the liner got almost within sight of the freighter she received a message that the crew of the Laleham had been rescued by the British tanker Shirvan, bound for Falmouth, England.

snippet: The rebels commenced an advance on both pikes yesterday morning, towards Elk Water and Cheat Mountain Summit. They succeeded in surrounding the fort on the summit, and cut the telegraph wire. They continued to advance on Elk Water until within two...
lead_paragraph: The rebels commenced an advance on both pikes yesterday morning, towards Elk Water and Cheat Mountain Summit. They succeeded in surrounding the fort on the summit, and cut the telegraph wire. They continued to advance on Elk Water until within two miles of our troops, when a few shells from Loomis' Battery dispersed them. Skirmishing was kept up all night.

lead_paragraph: REGINA, Assiniboia, Nov. 23. -- It is a fact not generally known to the public, though well understood to the grain trade of the Northwest, that in the new and far Canadian Northwest, in a province whose very name is a synonym for desolation, in Assiniboia, 1,000 miles to the north and west from the head of Lake Superior, are situated some of the largest and most successful wheat farms in the world.

headline: {u'main': u'Digging for Oil; Canada Is Unlocking Petroleum From Sand'}
snippet: Ten building cranes looming over North America's largest energy construction project here are the visible peaks of a $22 billion mountain range of oil investments that are quietly transforming this patch of Canadian wilderness into what may soon b...
lead_paragraph: Ten building cranes looming over North America's largest energy construction project here are the visible peaks of a $22 billion mountain range of oil investments that are quietly transforming this patch of Canadian wilderness into what may soon be the continent's leading oil producing area north of the Gulf of Mexico. Within five years, oil flowing south from Alberta's oil sands is expected to surpass the current output of one million barrels a day from Alaska's North Slope. By the end of the decade, two million barrels a day, the current production of Nigeria, is to be pumped from here into a North American pipeline network that stretches from Portland, Ore., to Portland, Me., helping feed a market in the United States that now consumes about 20 million barrels of oil a day.

lead_paragraph: TADOUSAC, River Saguenay, June 28. Salmon fishing is royal sport, and is conducted in many of the Canadian rivers that are tributary to the St. Lawrence in a thoroughly royal fashion. Rich men spend thousands of dollars for the sake of a month's fishing every year, and, all expenses being counted, some of them pay as much as $5 or $10 a pound for their fish.

headline: {u'main': u'Chippewas Push Claims For Land In Canada'}
snippet: To Rose Manning, it is a return to the "promised land," where she was born and where her navel cord lies in sacred Chippewa ground.   "I don't remember, of course, but there was a little ceremony to show my roots are here because a part of my body...
lead_paragraph: To Rose Manning, it is a return to the "promised land," where she was born and where her navel cord lies in sacred Chippewa ground. "I don't remember, of course, but there was a little ceremony to show my roots are here because a part of my body is already here," she said outside one of the barracks at the Ipperwash Military Reserve, on the shores of Lake Huron, 25 miles northeast of Sarnia.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. and Canada to Speed Tariff Cuts'}
snippet: The United States and Canada, which have agreed to wipe out practically all trade barriers before the year 2000, announced today that they would speed up some tariff cutting.   The move, covering $2 billion of two-way trade a year, could bring che...
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada, which have agreed to wipe out practically all trade barriers before the year 2000, announced today that they would speed up some tariff cutting. The move, covering $2 billion of two-way trade a year, could bring cheaper vegetable oil, beef, and assorted chemicals and machinery to consumers in both countries.

lead_paragraph: HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 13. -- Canadians were told today that the time would come when there would be no Dominion hymn to sing if the Dominion did not take measures for its naval defense. lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Dr. Guzman, the Nicaraguan Minister, has received, information, which he has communicated to the State Department, that the Nicaraguan Government has restored the exequatur of Sigmund C. Braida, the United States Consul at Grey-town, or, more properly, San Juan del Norte, who with Mr. Bingham, the British Consul, fell into the bad graces of the local authorities for the part taken by him in the Bluefields affair.

headline: {u'main': u'U.S. AND CANADA AGREE TO STUDY DAM PROJECT'}
snippet: United States and Candadian officials met here last week and agreed to set up a joint commission to try to resolve Canadian ecological concerns over a dam construction project in North Dakota.   The agreement last Tuesday followed Canada's submiss...
lead_paragraph: United States and Candadian officials met here last week and agreed to set up a joint commission to try to resolve Canadian ecological concerns over a dam construction project in North Dakota. The agreement last Tuesday followed Canada's submission on Oct. 3 of a formal note of protest to the United States about ''the potentially damaging features'' of the project, which, after 18 years of study and debate, is moving toward the ground breaking stage. The first phase of the North Dakota project calls for the creation of the Lone Tree reservoir in an area that lies between the watersheds for two river systems. The Canadian protest expressed Ottawa's underlying fears about the project, which are shared by many environmentalists in the United States.

lead_paragraph: IT is just a little too bad that the exigencies of publishing and publicity led Joseph Barber and Bobbs-Merrill to make too good a thing of the title and subtitle of this excellent study. This is not a book on "why the United States provokes Canadians''; it is a book about Canada today and its intricate relationship with the United States.

lead_paragraph: A World Trade Organization panel ruled today that the United States and Canada were entitled to nearly $125 million in sanctions from the European Union because of its illegal ban on hormone-treated beef. headline: {u'main': u"Pope's Canceled Visit Makes Mark in Canada"}
snippet: The log skeleton of a giant tepee casts a weak shadow across windblown snowdrifts that undulate like waves down to the frozen confluence of the Mackenzie and Liard Rivers. Buffalo tails and colored streamers lashed atop the frame seem to rattle in...
lead_paragraph: The log skeleton of a giant tepee casts a weak shadow across windblown snowdrifts that undulate like waves down to the frozen confluence of the Mackenzie and Liard Rivers. Buffalo tails and colored streamers lashed atop the frame seem to rattle in the cold, now hovering at 30 below zero. About 5,000 of the Roman Catholic faithful and the merely curious converged here in September to await the arrival of Pope John Paul II. Today, there are no footprints in the snow around the tepee that the Dene, as Canada's Indians call themselves, erected for the Pope at the Place Where the Two Rivers Meet. The Pope's visit to Fort Simpson was canceled when fog prevented his plane from landing and he pressed on with his visit to the rest of Canada. But like a stone that casts ripples in the water long after it vanishes, the cancellation still evokes among the Dene jumbled emotions of bitterness, cynicism, resignation and stoic faith.

headline: {u'main': u'VISIT TO CANADA'}

lead_paragraph: There never were two countries so mixed up together as Canada and the United States. Yet it would be wrong to feel in the slightest degree proprietary or complacent about Canadian-American relations. There are few things that roil Canadians more than the inveterate American habit of considering them as good Americans who simply happen to have been born north of the border.

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- In the Canadian wilds 140 miles north of Duluth what is believed to be one of the continent's richest iron ore deposits rests beneath a lake and 70,000,000 tons of mud, clay and gravel -- glacial residue. In one of the biggest and most hazardous dredging jobs on record, a Chicago company is removing both the lake and the lake bed to clear the way for full scale mining operations.

Feb. 16. -- Even in these days, when a billion-dollar steel plant is projected in the United States, the capitalist who moves with the times cannot afford to disregard the smelting enterprise that has just sprung into being at Sydney, Cape Breton, and which has been rendered possible by the existence of immense deposits of hematite iron at Belleisle, Newfoundland, the most remarkable ore formation of its kind in the world.

headline: {u'main': u'The Early Word: Obama Talks Trade in Canada', u'kicker': u'The Caucus'}
snippet: On his first foreign trip as president, Barack Obama intends to reassure Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper that the United States is committed to a robust trading relationship....
lead_paragraph: For the first foreign trip of his presidency, President Obama has chosen our neighbor to the north, and Thursday morning he will be in Ottawa for meetings with Canadian leaders, including Prime Minister Stephen Harper.

headline: {u'main': u'CANADA DEAL COST UTILITY $800,000; New England Gas & Electric Association Reports Sale in Nova Scotia. LOSS CHARGED TO RESERVE Results Are Announced by Other Public Service Corporations, With Comparisons.'}

lead_paragraph: The New England Gas and Electric Association, controlled by affiliates of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, lost $800,000 in 1935 in the sale of companies in Nova Scotia, said the annual report yesterday. Proceeds from the Nova Scotia sale were used to buy stocks of the New Bedford Gas and Edison Light Company, controlled by the association.

headline: {u'main': u'ARBITRATION TREATY HELD UP BY CANADA; She Desires to Substitute Her Own for British Machinery in Dealing With Us. MOVE ENTIRELY FRIENDLY But Experience Is Held to Prove She Can Handle Own Affairs to Advantage. Canadians Cite Experiences. Matters Requiring Adjustment.'}
snippet: LONDON, Feb. 4.--That delay in the conclusion of the new AngloAmerican arbitration treaty is due to failure to receive a reply from one of the Dominions was stated by Sir Austen Chamberlain in the Commons last week. That this Dominion is Canada ha...
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 4.--That delay in the conclusion of the new AngloAmerican arbitration treaty is due to failure to receive a reply from one of the Dominions was stated by Sir Austen Chamberlain in the Commons last week. That this Dominion is Canada has been generally surmised.

headline: {u'main': u"VAST TREASURE LIES IN 'GOD'S DUMP HEAP'; Both Canada and Newfoundland Seek The Right to Develop the Rich Wilderness of Labrador VAST TREASURE LIES IN 'GOD'S DUMP HEAP'"}
snippet: TITLE to "God's Dump Heap," or, as Labrador has also been called, "Land of Caen," is being contested before the Privy Council of Great Britain by the Dominion of Canada and the Colony of Newfoundland. Newfoundland claims part of the wilderness int...
lead_paragraph: TITLE to "God's Dump Heap," or, as Labrador has also been called, "Land of Caen," is being contested before the Privy Council of Great Britain by the Dominion of Canada and the Colony of Newfoundland. Newfoundland claims part of the wilderness interior of Labrador, while the Province of Quebec labels the country, on its maps, "Upper Quebec."

headline: {u'main': u'Diabetes and Other Ills Hit Indians in Canada'}
snippet: LITTLE BLACK RIVER INDIAN RESERVE, Manitoba --   As community health representative on this reservation of 447 Ojibwa Indians, Jackie McPherson helps deliver babies, bandages cuts, splints fractures and drives emergency cases in her 1988 Chrysler ...
lead_paragraph: LITTLE BLACK RIVER INDIAN RESERVE, Manitoba -- As community health representative on this reservation of 447 Ojibwa Indians, Jackie McPherson helps deliver babies, bandages cuts, splints fractures and drives emergency cases in her 1988 Chrysler LeBaron to the hospital in Pine Falls 28 miles away. The 2,000-acre reservation is in a remote area of pines and birches at the junction of the O'Hanly and Black rivers, 110 miles north of Winnipeg.

headline: {u'main': u'OFFER $10,000,000 PAPER MILL BONDS; Bankers Are Marketing Issue of Price Brothers & Co., Ltd., of Canada.'}
snippet: A new offering is being made today by Harris, Forbes  Co. of an original issue of $10,000,000 Price Brothers  Co., Ltd., first mortgage twenty-year sinking fund 6 per cent, gold bonds, Series A. due Feb. 1, 1943, at 98 1/2 and interest, yielding 6...
lead_paragraph: A new offering is being made today by Harris, Forbes Co. of an original issue of $10,000,000 Price Brothers Co., Ltd., first mortgage twenty-year sinking fund 6 per cent, gold bonds, Series A. due Feb. 1, 1943, at 98 1/2 and interest, yielding 6 1/8 per cent. The bonds are callable at 107 1/2 on Feb. 1, 1933, and at 3/4 per cent, less each year thereafter to maturity.
